words.definition: not perturbed or disconcerted
words.verbalIllustration: the protestors were unfazed by the prospect of arrest

words.definition: a child who behaves very badly : an annoying child
words.verbalIllustration: a bunch of ill-mannered little brats

words.definition: feeling or displaying no fear by temperament
words.verbalIllustration: undaunted despite their repeated failures at starting a business

words.definition: annoyed or angry
words.verbalIllustration: I was cross with her for being so careless

words.definition: to cause someone to be worried or upset
words.verbalIllustration: It perturbed him that his son was thinking about leaving school

words.definition: to look through (as a place) carefully or thoroughly in an effort to find or discover something
words.verbalIllustration: the owner of the bed-and-breakfast often trolls antique stores for furniture and knickknacks

words.definition: :to proceed or move quickly
words.verbalIllustration: everyone scurried back to work as soon as they had finished their lunch in the cafeteria

words.definition: to move or act slowly
words.verbalIllustration: if you continue to dawdle, we'll be late for sure

words.definition: to make an irregular series of quick, sudden movements
words.verbalIllustration: the housefly darted about the room until it found an open window and flew out

words.definition: :to put up (a sign, notice, etc.) so that it can be seen by many people
words.verbalIllustration: The professor posted (up) the students's exam grades outside her office

words.definition: :to make (something) officially known to many people
words.verbalIllustration: The company posted increased profits for the third quarter.

words.definition: :to add (a message) to an online message board
words.verbalIllustration: She posts regularly to several newsgroups.

words.definition: :to assign (someone, such as a guard) to stand or stay at a particular place
words.verbalIllustration: Paramedics were posted nearby.

words.definition: :a piece of wood or metal that is set in an upright position into or on the ground especially as a support or marker
words.verbalIllustration: fence posts

words.definition: :to set (something) in a tightly closed position
words.verbalIllustration: His jaw clenched and unclenched as he listened to the speech.

words.definition: :to hold (something) tightly
words.verbalIllustration: She danced alone, with a rose clenched in her teeth.

words.definition: :the act or manner of holding
words.verbalIllustration: fearful that his suitcase might be stolen, he never once relaxed his clench on the handle

words.definition: :to have or keep in one's hands
words.verbalIllustration: clenched a tissue in his hands as he told his story of misfortune

words.definition: :to have or keep in one's hands
words.verbalIllustration: he clutched the eggs carefully so he wouldn't drop them

words.definition: :to fasten (something) with a clasp
words.verbalIllustration: He clasped the keys to his belt

words.definition: :to hold (someone or something) tightly with your hands or arms
words.verbalIllustration: He clasped her hand gently/firmly.

words.definition: :to cause (as a person) to become filled or saturated with a certain quality or principle
words.verbalIllustration: invested the film with his own enthusiasm for the wonders of flight

words.definition: :to furnish freely or naturally with some power, quality, or attribute
words.verbalIllustration: a woman invested with the strong desire to make the world a better place

words.definition: :a number of things considered as a unit
words.verbalIllustration: a clutch of medals adorned the general's chest

words.definition: :a usually small number of persons considered as a unit
words.verbalIllustration: a clutch of people traveling together

words.definition: :a time or state of affairs requiring prompt or decisive action
words.verbalIllustration: a football quarterback who always comes through in the clutch

words.definition: :the right or means to command or control others
words.verbalIllustration: a nation no longer living in the clutch of a cruel tyrant

words.definition: :to make (someone) feel annoyed or angry
words.verbalIllustration: It galls me that such a small group of people can have so much power.

words.definition: to remain in place in readiness or expectation of something
words.verbalIllustration: decided to bide her time until she had an opportunity to switch jobs

words.definition: :something that can be used for a particular purpose
words.verbalIllustration: Now that he's a writer, he regards his difficult childhood experience as grist for the mill.

words.definition: :to read or look at something quickly
words.verbalIllustration: Please run your eye over this and let me know what you think.

words.definition: :to quickly read or look at (something, such as a list)
words.verbalIllustration: She ran her eye down the list looking for her name.

words.definition: :deeply involved in or affected by something
words.verbalIllustration: We're up to our eyes in work. [=we are very busy]

words.definition: an act or period of watching for signs of activity, danger, or opportunity
words.verbalIllustration: kept vigil at their ailing son's bedside the entire time he was in the hospital

words.definition: :unable to decide about something
words.verbalIllustration: He tried to persuade those still (sitting) on the fence to vote in his favor.

words.definition: 1:to start to be comfortable in a new situation 2:to begin to be confident or successful
words.verbalIllustration: 1. They quickly found their feet in their adopted country. 2. I was away for a long time, so it will take me a while to find my feet again.

words.definition: :a way to represent a list of items, each item in the list is a node, and a node contains two things, the value itself and a reference to the next node on the list
words.verbalIllustration: linked lists are a building block for more complex data structures

words.definition: :to feel great surprise, wonder, or admiration
words.verbalIllustration: The doctors marveled that anyone could recover so quickly.

words.definition: :to hang down loosely especially in a way that makes it possible to swing freely
words.verbalIllustration: He dangled a piece of string in front of the cat.

words.definition: :to offer (something) in order to persuade someone to do something
words.verbalIllustration: The money she dangled in front of him wasn't enough to convince him to sell.

words.definition: 1:a gap or blank space in something; 2:a missing part
words.verbalIllustration: She found a lacuna in the historical record.

words.definition: :a falling short of an essential or desirable amount or number
words.verbalIllustration: there was a dearth of usable firewood at the campsite

words.definition: :the fact or state of being absent
words.verbalIllustration: the dearth of salesclerks at the shoe store annoyed us

words.definition: :lost in thought and unaware of one's surroundings or actions
words.verbalIllustration: seemed absent when I told him you were coming because he nodded but didn't say anything

words.definition: :not having
words.verbalIllustration: absent a significant source of investment funds, the fledgling company continues to struggle

words.definition: :to fail to attend
words.verbalIllustration: She found a plausible excuse to absent herself from the gathering.

words.definition: :not having or showing complete trust in someone or something that could be dangerous or cause trouble
words.verbalIllustration: The store owner kept a wary eye on him.

words.definition: :taking, showing, or involving great care and effort
words.verbalIllustration: a scrupulous attention to detail is evident in all of his reporting

words.definition: :traditional knowledge, beliefs, and stories that relate to a particular place, subject, or group
words.verbalIllustration: [1]an event that has become part of local lore, [2]forest lore, [3]the lore of sailing

words.definition: :a body of facts learned by study or experience
words.verbalIllustration: the home gardener had acquired her herbal lore from many years of trial and error

words.definition: :to leave a place often for another
words.verbalIllustration: after two hours of that boring party, we were ready to bail

words.definition: :to move suddenly and sharply (as in surprise)
words.verbalIllustration: the sudden appearance of a mouse scurrying across the floor made me jump

words.definition: to do something without doing it very well or easily
words.verbalIllustration: I had a hard time with the class, but somehow I muddled through.

words.definition: to think, act, or proceed in a confused way or without a plan
words.verbalIllustration: She muddled along for a few years before going to college.

words.definition: :a disordered mixture
words.verbalIllustration: a muddle of documents

words.definition: :a state of mental uncertainty
words.verbalIllustration: the new, supposedly improved forms simply put taxpayers in a bigger muddle

words.definition: :something that curves or is curved
words.verbalIllustration: the road around the peninsula is all angles and hairpin turns

words.definition: :a way of looking at or thinking about something
words.verbalIllustration: what's your angle on the problem?

words.definition: :to try to get what you want in a clever or indirect way
words.verbalIllustration: She's been angling to get a promotion.

words.definition: :coming before all others in importance
words.verbalIllustration: since the start of her acting career her parents have steadfastly remained her arch supporters

words.definition: :to move or go very suddenly and quickly from or to a particular place, position, or condition
words.verbalIllustration: She bolted awake when the alarm sounded.

words.definition: [1]:to attach (something) firmly, [2]:to attach (something) with a bolt
words.verbalIllustration: [1]He bolted the panels together, [2]The bench was bolted to the floor.

words.definition: :to buy or take (something or someone) quickly or eagerly
words.verbalIllustration: Shoppers came to the store to snap up bargains after the holidays.

words.definition: :showing that you do not understand something or that you find something strange or amusing
words.verbalIllustration: She raised a quizzical eyebrow when she saw what he was wearing.

words.definition: :a long, complicated, and annoying process, description, etc
words.verbalIllustration: We had to go through the rigmarole of installing, registering, and activating the software before we found out it wouldn't work.

words.definition: :a long list of related things
words.verbalIllustration: He recited a laundry list of problems.

words.definition: :to make a list of (names, things, etc)
words.verbalIllustration: I listed my likes and dislikes.

words.definition: :to enter information about someone (something)
words.verbalIllustration: The hospital has listed him (as being) in fair condition.

words.definition: :to make jerky or restless movements
words.verbalIllustration: the executive fiddled with a pen as she impatiently waited for the meeting to begin

words.definition: :to spend time in aimless activity
words.verbalIllustration: we spent the snow day just fiddling aroung

words.definition: :to handle thoughtlessly, ignorantly, or mischievously
words.verbalIllustration: I could tell that someone had been fiddling with the carefully set controls on my entertainment system

words.definition: :to use up carelessly
words.verbalIllustration: fiddled away the entire evening

words.definition: :marked by or given to small uncontrollable bodily movements
words.verbalIllustration: the frail woman extended a tremulous hand in welcome

words.definition: :easily frightened
words.verbalIllustration: a tremulous girl somehow mustered up the courage to ask a question of the governor

words.definition: :to work hard to find or get (courage, support, etc)
words.verbalIllustration: He finally mustered (up) the courage to ask her on a date.

words.definition: :having an odd and amusing quality
words.verbalIllustration: a droll little man with a peculiar sense of humor

words.definition: :to walk with short steps while moving from side to side like a duck
words.verbalIllustration: [1]He waddled down the hallway. [2]A fat goose waddled across the yard.

words.definition: :nothing at all
words.verbalIllustration: She's done zilch to help me out.
